```{r setup, include=FALSE}
library(gofigR)
library(ggplot2)
library(plotly)

#source("~/dev/gofigr_r/gofigR/R/markdown.R")
source("~/dev/gofigr_r/gofigR/R/graphics.R")

knitr::opts_chunk$set(echo = TRUE)
enable(analysis_name="My first Rmd analysis 2",
       watermark = gofigR::QR_WATERMARK)
```

## R Markdown

This is an R Markdown document. Markdown is a simple formatting syntax for authoring HTML, PDF, and MS Word documents. For more details on using R Markdown see <http://rmarkdown.rstudio.com>.

When you click the **Knit** button a document will be generated that includes both content as well as the output of any embedded R code chunks within the document. You can embed an R code chunk like this:

```{r cars}
#summary(cars)

test <- function(...) {
  print(list(...)[1])
}

test(list(c(1, 2), c(3, 4)))
```


## Including Plots

You can also embed plots, for example:



```{r pressure, echo=FALSE, gofigr_figure_name="My first figure"}
plot(pressure, main="Pressure vs temperature")
```

```{r pressure2, echo=FALSE}
plot(pressure)
```

Note that the `echo = FALSE` parameter was added to the code chunk to prevent printing of the R code that generated the plot.

```{r barplot}
temperatures <- c(22, 27, 26, 24, 23, 26, 28)

# bar plot of temperatures vector
barplot(temperatures)

#plot(result)
```

```{r ggplot}
gp <- ggplot(data=pressure, mapping=aes(x=temperature, y=pressure))
gp <- gp + geom_line()
plot(gp)
```

```{r plotly}
library(plotly)

fig <- plot_ly(data = iris, x = ~Sepal.Length, y = ~Petal.Length)

fig
```
